comments.LineComment: | A children's book of recursion schemes. Each morphism is a chapter,
| shown as a full comic strip. Tabs let you flip between chapters.
| Panel diagrams are rendered via HATS into container divs.

value.value:
-- Evaluate an expression tree
eval :: Expr -> Int
eval = cata $ case _ of
  LitF n     -> n
  AddF x y   -> x + y
  MulF x y   -> x * y
  SubF x y   -> x - y

-- Build a countdown list from n to 1
countdown :: Int -> List Int
countdown = ana $ \\n ->
  if n <= 0
    then NilF
    else ConsF n (n - 1)

-- Factorial: unfold to list, fold with multiply
-- But the list is never actually built!
factorial :: Int -> Int
factorial = hylo multiply countdown
  where
  multiply NilF = 1
  multiply (ConsF n acc) = n * acc

-- Get all suffixes: [1,2,3] -> [[1,2,3],[2,3],[3],[]]
tails :: List a -> List (List a)
tails = para $ case _ of
  NilF -> [[]]
  ConsF x (Tuple originalTail results) ->
    (x : originalTail) : results

-- Insert into sorted list, reusing the tail
insert :: Int -> List Int -> List Int
insert n = apo $ \\xs -> case xs of
  x:rest | n > x -> ConsF x (Right rest)  -- keep going
  _              -> ConsF n (Left xs)     -- done! reuse xs

-- Fibonacci with full history
fib :: Nat -> Int
fib = histo $ case _ of
  ZeroF -> 0
  SuccF (Cofree _ ZeroF) -> 1
  SuccF (Cofree a (SuccF (Cofree b _))) -> a + b

-- Generate pairs: 1,1,2,2,3,3...
pairs :: Int -> List Int
pairs = futu $ \\n ->
  if n <= 0 then NilF
  else ConsF n           -- first n
         (Free (ConsF n  -- second n
           (Pure (n+1))))  -- then recurse with n+1

-- Check palindrome using length as helper
isPalindrome :: Eq a => List a -> Bool
isPalindrome = zygo len check
  where
  len NilF = 0
  len (ConsF _ n) = n + 1
  check NilF = True
  check (ConsF x (Tuple len (rest, ok))) =
    ok && (len <= 1 || x == last rest)
An algebra (f a -> a) collapses one layer. Cata applies it bottom-up until the whole tree becomes a single value.
A coalgebra (a -> f a) expands one layer. Ana applies it repeatedly, growing structure from a seed.
A coalgebra unfolds, an algebra folds. Hylo does both â€” but the compiler fuses them, skipping the intermediate structure!
Like cata, but the algebra receives a Tuple: the recursive result AND the original subtree, giving you memory.
Like ana, but the coalgebra can return Either: Left to stop early and reuse existing structure, Right to keep going.
Like cata, but the algebra receives a Cofree: the result decorated with ALL previous results in a chain.
Like ana, but the coalgebra can return Free: multiple layers of structure before needing to recurse again.
Two algebras: a helper (f b -> b) and a main (f (Tuple b a) -> a). The helper's result informs each step of the main fold.
cata :: Functor f => (f a -> a) -> Fix f -> a
ana :: Functor f => (a -> f a) -> a -> Fix f
hylo :: Functor f => (f b -> b) -> (a -> f a) -> a -> b
para :: Functor f => (f (Tuple (Fix f) a) -> a) -> Fix f -> a
apo :: Functor f => (a -> f (Either (Fix f) a)) -> a -> Fix f
histo :: Functor f => (f (Cofree f a) -> a) -> Fix f -> a
futu :: Functor f => (a -> f (Free f a)) -> a -> Fix f
zygo :: Functor f => (f b -> b) -> (f (Tuple b a) -> a) -> Fix f -> a
A friendly guide to recursion schemes
Click a morphism to explore. Arrows show "extends" relationships.
